description.text:
Get more velocity with a spring spacer for your Nerf HammerShot revolver. This spacer compresses your spring for more oomph while firing. Easy to install:
  • Make sure the gun isn't cocked.
  • Remove all screws from the gun and open the case.
  • Carefully remove the main spring from the grip area.
  • Slide the spacer onto the spring guide.
  • Replace the spring.
  • Reassemble the gun.
  • Play around with 20% more firepower!

description.text:
I grabbed a few Qi charging boards before the holidays to make chargers for my mom and dad. I was a bit jealous, so when I got home I ordered another for myself and here it is. I got the boards from Adafruit http://www.adafruit.com/products/2162. I use a nexus 5 if you use something else let me know and I can easily modify the model.
You can also use a logo of you choosing, I scaled this model of an opensource hardware logo for mine.

Non printed parts:
4 ea. 16mm M3
2 ea. 10mm M3
6 ea. M3 nuts
Super Glue
QI charger (http://www.adafruit.com/products/2162)
4 ea. rubber feet
  • Print both the top and base
  • Place Qi pcb in base, you will need to bend the wires connecting the charging base so be careful they are only just wrapped. In fact mind those wires throughout the assembly, just be slow.
  • Using the 4 16mm M3 bolts attach the cap of the base by first sliding the bolts into the upper half of the base, next the pcb's mounting holes,then finally lower half of the base. At this point mind the alignment if the pcb inside the base as it can be moved while tightening the bolts. Place 4 M3 nuts into the bottom of the lower half of the base to secure.
  • Using the 2 10mm M3 bolts attach the lower half of the top to the base, secure with 2 M3 nuts.
  • Place charging plate into the top and push all wires into the channel in the top itself.
  • Glue the face of the top on .
  • Finally glue you favorite logo into the relief in the face.

remixed_from.title: E3D Hot End Mount for Rostock

description.text:
This remix of H3SS's Hot End mount is a groove mount and is lighter and has an integral 25mm fan mount.   
This item has been used on two types of hot end. Most common a J-Head style Hot End or groove mounted device.  
The flat edge of this item is to attach a small fan to cool the Hot End barrel. It has two incorporated screw holes for fastening a 25mm fan.

• Print.
  • Trim out the supports on the Cap piece. This will allow the mount to slip into position.
  • Decide how and where you want to mount the two pieces: Top, Bottom or Elevated on a Rostock style effector or other machine.
  • Install.
  • Print.
    • Background:
    The Hot End mount was designed for the Hot End shown in the above pictures and a J-Head groove mount. It can be mounted in various positions (Top, Bottom or elevated.) on a Rostock effector. I mounted my J-Head elevated to provide more print height on my mini-Rostock and to incorporate special design features.

In 1953, Don Murphy set out to “devise a wholesome, constructive activity that would foster a closer father-son relationship and promote craftsmanship and good sportsmanship through competition … Within a year of its debut, the Pinewood Derby has been adopted for use in all Cub Scout packs. Estimates suggest that more than 100 million Cub Scouts have participated in the event over the past 55 years.” --excerpts from October 2008 Scouting magazine This is a box for determining whether a Pinewood Derby car is legal to race according to the rules of Pine Township Pack 344 (Seneca District):
  • Max. Length ≤ 7 in. (although the box is set to 7.1 in. to allow for a little flex)
  • Max. Width ≤ 2-3/4 in.
  • Wheel Base ≥ 1-3/4 in.
  • Bottom Clearance ≥ 3/8 in.
  • Front-End Flat (to ensure contact with starting pin) ≥ 1/4 in.

• Print the .stl file using 2 shells and >= 15% infill.
  • Break off the corner pancakes by scoring with a razor and snapping.
  • Enforce your Pinewood Derby rules at inspection!

description.text: This is a print I made for a two tier samurai sword stand I needed for my wall display.  The Stand came out great, but felt a bit weak when printed with 20% infill.  I redesigned it and there is a V2 out, but this one should print just nicely if you make sure your infill is in the 35-40% range.

There is a version 2 I made of this stand, and it is much sturdier.  Version 2 I printed with 40% infill.

author: jamesmay4847

description.text:
Watching prints in my dimly lit dining room is difficult on my eyes. So, I set out to light my print bed. This idea went from a desk lamp, to white LEDs, to the current seven color surround lighting. Included are a cover for a switching circuit and LED mounts. I am using 5050 RGB LEDs. This allows for the following color mixes:
Red
Green
Blue
Cyan (Green + Blue)
Yellow (Red + Green)
Magenta (Red + Blue)
White (Red + Green + Blue) EDIT 1/14/2015: I have added a schematic, a BOM, and some instructions in response to the number of views and downloads within 24hrs of posting.

Bill of Materials Purchase:
Three RGB LEDs
Four 400 to 600 Ohm resistors
Four switches
Wires, solder, circuit board, etc. Print:
Three LED Covers
Electronics Cover Instructions:
After acquiring or printing the materials above you will need to wire the LEDs, resistors, and switches together. Please see the images above for a schematic. The circuit I designed has a master power switch allowing you to turn the lights on and off. This is unnecessary, but I like to be able to switch off the lights when natural lighting is abundant. The three other switches allow you to choose and mix each color (RGB) individually. My power supply is burning the LEDs at 12 volts and each LED's loop in the circuit is drawing about 21 mA of current because of the 550 Ohm resistors. The 5050 LEDs will function with a reduced lifetime at higher currents. I recommend a 400 to 600 Ohm resistor for each loop. Adjust accordingly for your power supply.

Want to transport your RepRap without having to re-align, re-tighten and generally re-calibrate your bot? This set of things will allow you to secure your RepRap Prusa Mendel i1 or i2 to a piece of wood, typically plywood, so it can be moved without tweaking your frame. It also has the benefit of stabilizing the machine, improving prints.

The foot restraints keep the machine from shifting and the tiedowns keep the machine in the restraints.  
Print four foot restraints and 4-6 tiedowns. Position your machine on a piece of plywood (1/2" or more thick) and mark the location of the feet. Screw down the foot restraints in place, then mark the center lines between feet. Along the lines screw down some tiedowns. Do not put any of them in the center of the span between feet because parts of the machine will be in the way. Use zip ties to secure the threaded rod frame to the enclosure tiedowns.

Useless arduino without the arduino. I had a really tough time editing
the existing STL files, so I re-drew everything except the lever. This version requires a modified servo, a DPDT toggle and a Lever Switch.
Thanks KosselOwner for the realllllly cool original design. Hope you dont mind my tinkering :)

I have printed several of these with the Makerware default settings.
Modify a servo into a simple geared motor. The mod is shown in the pics.zip file.
Solder the connections and assemble everything.
Put the lever on the servo.
Install the servo. (wiring07 shows orientation)
Align the toggle switch where the power wires are closest to the
edge.
Most of the time, the lever switch will fit tight enough to just stay in
place. If not, glue it. The toggle switch is a 2 position double pole double throw on-on switch from RadioShack. The lever switch is just a small micro-switch with a lever (also purchased from radio shack)
Note: The toggle switches with the plastic toggles seem to be very hard to press.. I recommend using one that is all metal (easier to toggle back and forth)
Oh!! One last note. If things seem to be working backwards, reverse the power wires!!

comments.text:
Thats a really cool remix!
Another option would be to use an ATtiny85, since 2 digital IOs are sufficient.
Since the Uno is very cheap (~2.50€), I didn't bother redesigning my useless machine.
Thanks for the credit :)

Once upon a time i was looking for a printing platform for my printrbot simple after I had upgraded its print area. This lead me down the usual rabbit hole for a flat and available surface to print on.
Things tried:
  • Glass from an old computer scanner - I cracked three before giving up on them, they are tempered glass and will not be cut. After that they shattered from heat shocks.
  • Home Depot Glass Pains - These could be cut but cracked when shocked from heat.
  • Aluminum Sheets - This is a very popular option and I hear it works well. When i tried it i did not get the aluminum milled flat and it was too thin no to bend. I find that metals are too ductile to provide a flat surface. I know that a proper piece of aluminum is the favorite choice of many but with shipping the cost is too much.
  • Mirrors - I got two glass mirrors from reprap.me and loved them, they were the right size and have yet to crack. Best part though, they were $5! Cheaper than getting glass pains from the local hardware store. The only problem with mirrors are the thickness and they do not always come in the sizes I need.
    • This leads me to my current build plate, its a 200x300mm by 2mm thick carbon fiber board. Carbon fiber is very strong so it will hold its shape. When I ordered a board form ebay I did not know if it would be flat enough to print on. Upon examination the board is very very flat. It also has a nice shinny and glass like surface thanks to the resin that the fiber is bonded in. When i try to bend the board in my hand it flexes very little. Other things to note about the carbon fiber, it was cheap from china. There are some defects in the layout of the fiber but that does not affect the smoothness of the board at all. I wouldn't go thinner than 2mm thick and if the print surface needs to be bigger I would recommend a 3mm thick sheet for a comfortable level of rigidity. This is my first week with the carbon fiber bed so I will post any updates that will find! UPDATE 2/4/2015:
    No problems with the build plate. I use glue sticks as an adhesive. I get a lot less curling problems than with the glass beds I used. As long as there is glue down the print will stick and will be flat. I have sense printed a large object on the bed with no problems, 250mm long.

Find a carbon fiber sheet on ebay that is the right size.
Clamp it to your heated bed. (or non heated)
Apply coating of glue stick for optimal adhesion. I have yet to try out anything but PLA but the surface acts like glass so an ABS slurry should work well.

comments.text:
I have a carbon sheet, too. It is hold in place by a simple holder clamped at the z axis, without any clamps on the heated bed. My sheet is only 0.5mm thick, so far without any visible bending. While I have never tried glass, FR4, PEI, glue sticks or ABS slurry I'd say it is quite good.

comments.text: Things have been going very good. I was able to print an object 250mm long with no problem. The intergraty of the resign is my only minor issue; a blade will cut it if I'm not careful. Otherwise, it's been perfect.

comments.text: It's the blade cutting it that would concern me  what attempting to seperate the print from the bed.  I routinely have to use a xacto knife to split the two apart when using borosylicate.
comments.author: Sbbrain

comments.text:
I have been using the board for quite some time and here are my thoughts about that. I use a layer of glue stick under every PLA print and have had no problems with warping and they come off great after it cools down. I use a razor blade and have yet to scratch the surface from removing the print.
ABS is another story. I just got my first batch but it sticks a lot harder to the board. I use an acetone slurry on top of the glue stick and it is hard to get off. Still I have not scratched it from this. Most scratches come from the print head being way to low. Once I was not careful while cleaning the board with a razor blade and that scratched it. These are never noticeable though because the glue is needed for adhesion anyways. I would say because of the glue minor scratches are a non issue.
comments.author: wdsparrow

comments.text: Buy your plate glass from a glass supplier and have the edges rounded. The ground edges will prevent the glass from cracking. It works great and my 200x200x3mm plate cost around $3. A window repair place will stock the glass, cut it and round the edges for cheap.
comments.author: Battman540

comments.text: Very interesting, please keep us updated. Which plastics have you tried to print and what's your experience of each?
comments.author: pdumke

comments.text: I can confirm that ABS sticks very well to a carbon fiber plate without any preparation. With ABS juice you get extra sticking power, if you really need it. I haven't used anything else for ABS since I got the plate about a year ago.
comments.author: pdumke

comments.text:
So far I have only used PLA, its my main plastic. I applied a coating of glue before the print and there were no problems with curling at all. Though after the plate had cooled, it was notably harder to remove the parts than removing them from glass. The glue seems to adhere the carbon plate much more than it did to glass.
I might try a test print without the glue to see if it is even necessary.

title: Super Punch Out!! Arcade "Ducking Pull" 5-Way Joystick Conversion Bracket

description.text: This is used to convert an original Punch Out!! arcade joystick into a 5-way joystick, used for Super Punch Out!! The original kits are very difficult to find, and expensive when they do pop up... and Mike's Arcade reproduced the kit several years ago, but sold out, and again, are hard to find and expensive. So I decided to make my own, for just a few bucks, and a little bit of time. Super Punch Out!! was an upgrade kit for the Punch Out!! arcade game by Nintendo. Rather than simply creating new fighters, they also changed the gameplay a bit by adding the ability to duck, rather than simply being able to block, dodge, and punch. This involved changing the joystick for one that could pull to duck ("Ducking Pull", referring to the label on the overlay). This part is a bracket that holds the microswitch for the "pull" direction. Also needed is a knob, or other bell shaped object to attach to the bottom of the joystick shaft, to press the microswitch, as well as the microswitch itself, and misc. hardware (screws, etc). Instructions for the entire modification are available on the KLOV forums: http://forums.arcade-museum.com/showpost.php?p=2967987&postcount=24

I printed this bracket in ABS, using standard settings (0.3mm layer height, 10% infill, etc). There are two small spans where the nuts slide in, as well as a couple sideways holes for the screws... so depending on your printer, you may need support material. I personally printed without supports, and it bridged the spans just fine (I didn't feel like trying to clear out the excess support plastic from inside the small holes). Once you print this part, go to the KLOV forums to get the instructions for the full 5-way joystick modification: http://forums.arcade-museum.com/showpost.php?p=2967987&postcount=24

author: luodanli

remixed_from.author: mitchellcook5
remixed_from.title: Dead Simple Anti-Vibration Mount for Mobius/GoPro

description.text:
I designed this mount for a mobius camera but any small cam should work the same. I have it mounted to my F450 Quadcopter via some strong velcro i got from hobbyking but zip ties would also work.
It is designed to allow for the servos full range of motion when the servo is centered horizontally. The dimensions of the flat plate are 40mm x 60mm and the earplug holes are 6mm. The foam earplug idea came from mitchellcook5 and his Dead Simple Anti-Vibration Mount for Mobius/GoPro A video: http://youtu.be/Vjv-sLNSWAM

Additional Items Needed: 1x 9g Servo http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=662 4x Foam Earplugs Some Velcro http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__9374__Polyester_Velcro_Peel_n_stick_adhesive_side_V_STRONG_1mtr_.html Print one of each part using about 60% - 80% infill and no supports, I used a layer height of 0.2mm and ABS for extra strength. The flat piece is mounted directly to the copter by velcro (or zip ties) and the foam earplugs are inserted from the side with rounded holes to help it sit flatter. The next piece with the holes in it is secured only by the foam earplugs with a little CA glue to stop them slipping out, they do fit very tightly though. The last piece, which the camera is mounted on, has the servo screwed to it by slipping it in the square bracket with the output shaft in the center then using the mounting holes provided to screw it in place. (remove the servo horn before doing this) To attach this to the rest of the mount first place the servo horn in the hole on the mobius_mount_bottom piece and secure it using the two screw holes there. Next push the servo shaft back onto the horn and tighten the screw, it should now be complete. (Remember to center the servo before attaching it) The pictures should help a lot with assembly :)

Hi EPatt
In the current design I do not "forward" the video-output signal. Mostly because I don't use it. However the connection is still on the RPI board so it's just a matter of taking a short cable and pull it out through any of the "ventilation" holes. If you want it in a more fancy way, just re-design one of the parts (using SketchUp) with a new hole for a connector like this: http://www.showmecables.com/product/RCA-Jack-Chassis-Mount-Connector.aspx then just connect it to the RPI. :)

description.text:
This replaces the default filament guide that comes with the Makergear M2 printer. My filament was kinking and stopping the printer because of all the sideways pull, and this solves that problem.
This also helps if you are using FluidDoc's smaller M2 Spool holder (Thing 31305) or if you have one of the wider-profile spools like the JET spools sold on Amazon.
If you like my designs, let me know with a little bitcoin:
16QaNzCAGKhyjAtwPhy9WxNk8NRhzw8rk7

Print the file as is, with no support.  The five guide holes will need bridging, so make sure your bridging settings are good to go.  The bolt holes on the bottom are chamfered at 45 degrees, so they will not need any support.

title: Power Supply Mounting for the Replicator

description.text:
This thing facilitates mounting a common imported 24V power supply beneath the build chamber of a Replicator.  The standoffs are connected by a frame, so you don't have to deal with four separate standoffs.  Instead of mounting the power supply flush to the bottom plate, the standoffs ensure that the cooling cutouts on the power supply frame aren't blocked.  The frame and standoffs also serve as a drilling guide to position the drilled holes in the Replicator bottom plate.  
The mounting holes are positioned for the most common imported type power supply.  The positions can be changed easily by adjusting the parameters in the OpenSCAD file.  
Note that this thing is specifically not available in customizer, as that is one of the main pollutant sources that make Thingiverse practically unusable.

I printed in ABS at 0.2mm layer height, 25% infil.  The width and thickness of the frame that I used are probably overkill.  They could  be reduced by adjusting parameters in the OpenSCAD file.  
If necessary, ream out the mounting holes in the standoffs so they clear the 4mm screw threads.  The screws should not tap into the standoffs.  
Decide where you want the power supply on the underside of the build chamber, and position the standoff frame appropriately; tape it in place.  
Either mark the holes to be drilled, using the frame as a guide, or just drill through the frame and the Replicator bottom plate.  Avoid hitting any wires or other mechanics/electronics.  
You can just leave the standoff frame taped in place, and insert the four, M4-15 screws and washers from the inside of the build chamber.  Position the power supply and tighten the screws.  
Caution, the mounting screws should not penetrate the power supply frame by more than 4mm.  With the current values in the OpenSCAD file, the penetration distance should be less than this assuming that a 15mm length screw is used with a washer and 5mm thick base plate.

title: LM-2596 Voltage Regulator Mounting Box w/lid.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
5/18/2015 updated so the screw tabs/ziptie clips are at the ends for tight fits. second version. lid still fits this version.
Box for LM-2596 adjustable dc voltage regulator. There is an opening in each end for the input and output wires. The lid is designed to snap on tightly.
Printed with 2 shells and 35 percent infill. Depending on your print setting you may have to adjust print settings or even sand the inner lid edges of your box lid to make it fit.
Designed for lm2596 voltage regulators commonly found on ebay and amazon. This box fits boards that measure 48mm x 23mm with wires soldered on each end and a variable resistor to set the output voltage.(shown in photos) It may need to be modified or resized for other boards.
A remix of a case for a larger regulator. The original can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:547827

description.text: Pinza de la ropa, es un ejemplo de un objeto cotidiano impreso en 3d.

A fan mount to redirected the air for better print cooling on the Leapfrog Creatr.
I had problems with melting prints caused by trapped hot air under the nozzle.
This design was a major improvement on the prints that came out.
It cools the print but also the incoming filament (where the fans ware originally mounted for). The 2 air-blocks slide in ware the fans usually are mounted. The fans are than mounted on the outside of the metal casing with wood screws, mounting the air-blocks with the same screws together. NOTE: The print volume in width decreases by +/- 40 mm

- UPDATE -
  • V2.2: Left and right fan mount

I'm Sander, creator of this 3D Print. And founder of my own 3D Scan & Design service:

comments.text:
I made only right block (because i want have full printed area), thank You 4 design.
Photos in "I made it" 'll be later, now only words.
I not sure, but afraid this design may have problems with cooling all the system.
So I decided to use more effective coolers, 2 Jamicon KF0420S2H--R were found at home (of cause many other models from different manufactures are suitable too).First fan was set in left position instead of standart to garantee good cooling of motors and filament. After setting up the second fan and all system I started to print. Your design not worked good in my edition because my fan system was too effective and right hotend max temperature is too low for normal work (about 215-225C max). Solution of this problem is simple and consists 2 points
1) make right fan less effective by decresing it's power voltage - i used 560 Ohm resistor to have 11V on it (instead of standart 23-24V). (change voltage only on right fan, left fan must work on native 24V as designed by LeapFrog)
2) out holes of your design produce too strong wind on (right) hotend. Temporary idea was to close nearly all vertical holes with adhesive tape to find how many % of holes and where is nessesary to close for good working, on photo later 'll be my final solution.
The way to find max right cooling was simple - i heated right hotend to it's max temperature with closed holes of right block and then combining 1) (changing voltage on fan) & 2) (changing form/configuration of holes) made working system with temperature only 4-6 degree С lower.
After all this modifications i printed right block again. Printing and result with your design was better than the first printing without system, for example, the top of printing was printed with seen higher quality. Thank You.

author: adricat

description.text:
I recently bought a Garmin Forerunner 620 GPS watch. Great watch, but the wristband was just a little too small for my wrist. Since they only have 1 size I decided to make an extension element of about 10 mm.  
For my wrist 2 extension elements are plenty to securely fit the watch onto my wrist now.  
To fit the extra elements onto the watch I bought an extra wristband and used the special bolds and nuts to that came with it to securely install the extensions.  
Using the same black color PLA as the rubber wristband itself it looks as if it's a factory extension. It should fit the FR 220 as well, since they use the same size wristband.  
Sketchup design is made with Sketchup Make 2014.  
It was printed on a UltiMaker 1 (2011Q1?model) with all the official improvements and a heated bed with a glass sheet on top.

Just print and and fine-tune.
BOM:
  • PLA or ABS
  • Garmin extra wristband (productcode: 010-11251-28) approx. €19,-

title: ZYYX Webcam Holder - Keeping an eye on your prints

description.text: This design is for printing and mounting a D-Link camera on your printer. This is great if you want to watch your printer and the progression it’s making anytime, anywhere!

The first thing you will need is a D-Link camera. We use the DCS-930L and the design we have made is for this specific model. You will also need to pick your preferred plastic filament, we recommend black PLA. The final things you will need is a good double-sided tape.  
One of the designs, the actual holder, is printed with rafts and supports. After the print is done you will therefor have to remove the excess material. The ZYYX-tag is printed with without supports and raft to get a smooth surface so that the tape will stick better.  
After you have printed the designs, place an appropriate amount of double-sided tape on the backside of the ZYYX-tag and stick it to the printer as shown in the pictures. Put the camera in the holder and mount the holder on the tag.   
To start using your ZYYX Camera you will need to set up an account at MyDlink. With this you will be able to enjoy your printers creation from your phone, tablet or computer anytime, anywhere!

This amazing spider has 6 legs : it's the Hexaspider.
It is completely articulated and has two little compartments you can hide things into. Two-colored, three-colored or multicolored, imagine your own spider. Then, print it and you will have an unique hinged spider. STL were separated to allow you to customize your spider. It can be used as a toy for children (+ 4 years because of the small parts) or as a decorative object. A unique work printed in 3D! Please, like and share if you enjoy it :)

Pack 1 & 2 form the complete model.
"Détail" contains the separated parts. Layer height : 0.08 (or 0.1)
Fill: 20 %
Shell thickness : 1.6 mm or 4 shells
Bottom / Top thickness : 1.2 mm
Temp: 205
Speed while extruding : 40 mm/s The model was printed according to these settings. It must be kept so the mechanical elements to keep good friction properties.
With these parameters, no running screws or rectification with file have been necessary.

description.text:
I was searching for a combo stand to hold my iPhone and Beats Pill speaker. I came up empty, so I designed this stand using TinkerCAD.  
Enjoy!

My design approach for this project was to explore the use of friction fit parts using pin connectors contributed by another creator on Thingiverse. In addition, I wanted to act on best practices for printing parts in the best orientation for 3D printing. The design is composed of (4) major parts: base, sides, and seat. There are (8) pin connectors that hold the assembly together. I did eventually use glue to make the assembly permanent. An access hole for the charging cable for the player above is included in the design. Pin Connectors v3 by emmett

This is a set of pieces to build your own modular bridge or overpass. Ideal for war games or your kids' Matchbox cars. Pier height should be good for 3 stacked layers of 1-1/2" foam insulation if that's your terrain construction material of choice. Works well with my Jersey Barriers: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:55070 April 10, 2013: All old files have been updated and replaced. New files for complete set added. April 27, 2013: Slight changes to short beam & road end for better end-piece-only short bridge option. Added 3-column pier support as an alternative option. Removed "Work in progress" tag, but I'll probably keep adding new bits from time to time.

Print two long beams for each center road section. Print two short beams and one abutment for each end section. Print one pier for each joint between road sections. For a very short bridge, you could use two end sections, two long beams, and two abutments.  
The road section is drawn at 180mm x 180mm. If your print bed is smaller, scale all parts accordingly. 67% should still work well for Matchbox cars, Hot Wheels, etc. while still using two stacked layers of foam insulation to carve terrain.

title: Two Tier Samurai Sword Stand v2.1

description.text: Version 2.1 of the samurai sword stand I created.  This one has much thicker 10mm fingers to hold your swords.  The internal gap between fingers is a much tighter 25mm, and keeps your swords held vertically with a lot less play than v1.
This version was printed with 40% infill with clear PLA and is very solid.

comments.text: Looks like these are being stored edge down. That is not a good thing for this style of sword, though I'm not sure how much one cares with stainless steel replicas. Proper storage involves edge up, so that there is no chance the blade edge resting or rubbing on the scabbard.

description.text:
A clip to keep 1.75 mm filament from unraveling off the spool.
I know, there's a bunch of these on Thingiverse, I tried a few but felt I could do better. So here it is... Yet Another Filament Clip.
It's small and quick to print
Lays flat on the spool, doesn't stick out
Zigzaggy channel is easy to load but grips the filament

Put filament in straight channel
Slide clip around spool until it is past the end of the filament
Put ent of filament in zigzag channel and pull snug

title: High Flow Mini Shower Head withSpreading Pattern. Fast Easy print.

description.text: I tried one of the customizable shower heads.   In order to get a wide pattern, you will have to print a very large object..On this head, each passage is ported at an angle. The pattern will cover the width of the shoulders.   No swaying back and forth to get entirely wet.   The ports are .175 inch diameter which will print at around .125 inches.  This head will go through a ton of water.  I set my valve to half flow and still get plenty wet and the wife can go to full power to wash her hair.  Sometimes its faster to design something you need rather than searching for hours and not get what you want.  If you like to take long showers,  This head is not for you, or get a large water heater.  :)
No infill or supports required.  I print at 0.1 catfill infill at .2mm layer height.  The pipe threads are extra wide for FDM printers.

author: simonPrein

title: Monitor mount for laptop webcam pcb

description.text: I vaguely wanted a webcam for my desktop, but not enough to pay for one. I did however have several old laptops to take apart with inbuilt webcams. Frequently they use usb - so you just have to splice a usb cable onto the board. This case just lets you glue in one such board, and then hangs discreetly on top of your monitor.

Check to see whether your webcam pcb is usb (if it has four wires, red green black and white then it probably is usb). Try soldering wires of the same colours to a cut-off usb cable and plug it in to see if it works. If it does, great, otherwise you could try swapping wires (for some reason I've found usb cables with non-standard colours.)
Print (I used slic3rs support option, with 5mm spacing which worked very well)
I used hot glue to attach the board to the recess on the back, then soldered the wires in the small groove on the print. I hotglued the cable to the back of the case as stress-relief. I glued some thin strips of inner tube to the inside for grip, though this was probably not necessary/other rubbery things would work too.

title: Yazzo Tube Attach for Pololu Universal Motor Mount

description.text:
I have need to attach a bar or or tube, securely to the shaft of a motor. I purchased these universal motor mounts from Pololu: http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/1203 That part gives you a nice solid aluminum chunk with 4 machine screw holes on it. Then I just had to figure out how to utilize that part to connect my carbon fiber tubes. This thing brings the universal mount together with the tube at a 90 degree angle to the shaft. Very good when you're trying to use the motor as the muscle behind a swinging arm. Although this this is very similar to this other thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6164 It is not strictly a derivative, as it's design is completely different and the only thing they share is the ability to connect a tube to a motor shaft.

1) Print one of these out, assuming you've purchased the Pololu motor mount thing.
2) Put the set screw into the motor mount, but don't tighten it all the way.
3) Slip the universal mount into this thing
4) Align the universal mount such that the set screw faces the opening in the outside of the tube
5) Put 4 #4-40 screws into the universal mount from the outside of this thing. Basically tighten the universal mount to the body of this thing.
6) Slip the whole assembly over the motor shaft, and tighten the set screw until it is secure.
7) Slip your tubing or rod into the other opening
8) Rejoice! The OpenScad is provided, and you can change anything from the thickness of the universal mount you have, to the hole spacing, size of tubes, etc.

I've been feeding filament from an external spool on my DaVinci 1.0 using my Big Spool Holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:583800), which was derived from Ranh316's DaVinci Rear Filament Spool Hanger (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:409100).
Works OK but I don't like the built in filament guide: It crimps the filament if you open the top too far and makes changing filament tricky. I tried passing the filament directly through the rear slot, but it tends to pull the filament off the side of the spool, eventually resulting in a jam.
So I made this filament guide, which clips to the rear slot and keeps the filament feeding properly. It doesn't require any modifications to the printer.

I printed it with XYZWare's Good setting.
Mount it in the slot as seen in the photo. Filament runs from the spool through the guide, rear slot, and the plastic tube, then to the extruder.

description.text:
I wanted to try and see if I could make a copy of my own head. So with the aid of my wife and a garden chair and 123d catch I created this.  
I tidied uo the mesh on MeshMixer by Autodesk and also melded it into a plinth I found on this site and HEY PRESTO! a museum bust.  
Though to be honest the spectacles make me look a little like Dr Nefario from Despicable Me!

Wall mount for the 2014 Mac mini, may work on other models but unable to confirm. Has 4 mounting holes and cable channel access to rear of computer. To use insert the clips in the fan exhaust holes first then lift it into the 'hook' at the bottom. This will reduce the amount of stress on the clips.
UPDATE: Modified the file to a 100x100 VESA standard so it can be mounted to the back of some televisions.

comments.text:
Printed okay on a Flashforge Dreamer using cnorrick's spliit file and a bit of rotating although print was right up against the edges.
Printed using PLA with 15% infill and unfortunately both the tips at the top broke on first use. May try again using a bit more care when inserting!
comments.author: qdex

comments.text: I've found that if you insert the pegs at the top first then lift the computer so it slides into the 'hook' at the bottom second it's a lot easier to manage.
comments.author: qdex

comments.text: I made one but the clip at the top broke immediately.  So I had to use a velcro strap because I did not trust the  other clip not to fail.  Otherwise works great and using it now.  If you post the step files I would like to change the design at the top to make it beefier.  Best wall mount design I could find.
comments.author: Kardacian

comments.text: You may have to increase the interior fill and print with supports in order to strengthen the clip. If you look at the VESA compatible STL I had already increased the thickness of the clips, I should probably make the same change to the original one or delete it. It's also helpful to engage the top clips first before you drop it into the bottom support, removing it by lifting the computer out of the bottom support worked well for me.
comments.author: Kardacian

description.text: Headphones

After building a Thing-o-Matic I had to create something from scratch. I was inspired by a nearby Cadbury Creme Egg and made this small egg cup. I was designing it with CSG in my head with the idea of using OpenSCAD (cylinder minus torus minus sphere, basically) when I noticed the Alibre icon and decided to see if "revolve boss" would get the job done quicker. In some sense the design is parametric, since you could load the AD_PRT file and modify the dimensions in the sketch (or even drag the shapes around within the constraints I set, like the 3mm top lip). Update: Perhaps it inspired this real egg cup? http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6620
